sub_topic: Probability of a certain demographic group being affected by a disease
message_1: What is the probability that out of 100 people randomly selected from a certain demographic group, exactly 5 will be affected by a certain disease, given that the overall prevalence of the disease in the group is 10%?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the binomial probability formula, which is:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of exactly k successes (in this case, people affected by the disease) in n trials (in this case, 100 people selected)
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- p is the probability of success (in this case, the prevalence of the disease, which is 10% or 0.1)
- n is the number of trials (in this case, 100 people)
- k is the number of successes (in this case, 5 people affected by the disease)

Plugging in the values, we get:

P(X = 5) = C(100, 5) * 0.1^5 * (1-0.1)^(100-5)

First, we need to calculate C(100, 5), which is the number of ways to choose 5 people out of 100:

C(100, 5) = 100! / (5! * (100-5)!)
C(100, 5) = 100! / (5! * 95!)

Using a calculator or software to compute the factorials, we get:

C(100, 5) = 75,287,520

Now, we can plug this value back into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 5) = 75,287,520 * 0.1^5 * 0.9^95

Using a calculator or software to compute the powers and the product, we get:

P(X = 5) â‰ˆ 0.010475

So, the probability that exactly 5 out of 100 people randomly selected from the demographic group will be affected by the disease is approximately 1.05%.
